question: Retell the story of Corinna’s farewell to her parrot as if you are Corinna, writing in her personal diary. Include the role of Isis as invoked in the triplets.
gold_answer: Diary Entry — Today was a day of sorrow. My beloved parrot, companion and confidant, was snatched away by envious fate, taken from my side. I said my farewells with heavy heart. In my grief, I called upon Isis, hoping she would turn her features to me and grant comfort. The gods are distant, yet my pain feels as if I am born to be a cause of trouble to my lover.
llm_answer:
Diary of Corinna  
(undated, the night after the seventh day)

I write by lamplight, my eyes still hot with tears. My little echo, my feathered mimic, is gone. All week I fasted, I sat in Isis’ temple on her appointed days, the Galli twining laurels while I prayed—not for myself this time, but for the small green life that perched on my shoulder and learned every cadence of my voice. I had hoped the Goddess, who keeps the serpent coiled around her altars and lets the horned Apis walk in her train, would turn her face toward us and spare him. I promised her frankincense, white robes, an inscription: “Naso, for the preservation of Corinna’s parrot, offers these.” Yet the seventh dawn arrived, and with it his faltering breath.

He took only a nut at breakfast, a drop of water at noon; poppies lulled him to sleep each dusk. Today his tongue, always quicker than any bird’s, managed one last sentence—my name, and farewell—before the thread snapped. I laid him in a coffin no larger than his body, set a stone above it: “From this very tomb I may be judged to have been the favorite of my mistress. I had a tongue more skilled at talking than other birds.”

I imagine him now in the Elysian grove reserved for innocent birds: holm-oak shade, ever-green grass, swans, the Phoenix, Juno’s peacock, and my chatterer among them, calling newcomers with human words. If Isis rules there too, may she let him keep his voice.

I close this page; the lamp flickers like his last heartbeat. Vale, my echo. Corinna.
